objects.author: Kelly Lyell
objects.title: Wastewater testing at CSU shows signs of COVID-19 at Moby Arena, Durrell Center
objects.html:
Editor's note: We're making this story free to read due to public safety concerns. But we rely on the support of subscribers to be able to do this work. Please help us by subscribing to the Coloradoan.

Colorado State University’s mandatory testing for COVID-19 based on wastewater measurements has been expanded to include all employees working in or around Moby Arena and Durrell Center, school officials said Tuesday.

The university is also requiring all members of the Kappa Sigma fraternity who live in a chapter house off campus to be tested for COVID-19 after learning of positive tests among five residents.

Mandatory testing of 509 residents of Braiden Hall, based on wastewater measurements indicating the presence of COVID-19, led to seven positive tests Friday, CSU spokeswoman Dell Rae Ciaravola told the Coloradoan in an email Tuesday. CSU also mandated tests Friday for 157 students living in a building at University Village, based on COVID-19 measurements of its wastewater.

CSU reported eight positive tests among students Friday, and it was not immediately clear whether or not the additional positive test was from a student at University Village.

The university has also asked the residents of Corbett Hall, chapter houses of all fraternity and sorority houses, and all graduate teaching assistants to get a free test from the university for COVID-19, the illness caused by the novel coronavirus.

CSU has tested more than 10,300 students, faculty and staff members on campus since Aug. 17, when students began moving into residence halls for the fall semester. About 7,400 of those tests were administered to students and staff associated with residence halls at the start of the school year, Ciaravola said. The other 2,900 or so tests have been given to targeted groups based on wastewater testing or other identified strategic testing of certain groups, such as fraternity and sorority members and graduate teaching assistants.

CSU has reported 118 positive tests for COVID-19 since it first started tracking cases May 21.

The university had 34,166 students last fall and was expecting about a 5% drop in this year's enrollment, Leslie Taylor, the vice president for enrollment and access, said recently. The official enrollment won't be counted until later this month, a school spokesman said Tuesday night. CSU had 1,904 faculty members and 5,772 staff in 2019-20, according to an annual report.

The university identified 589 employees who work in the area around Moby Arena and the Durrell Center over the weekend and offered them free testing, Ciaravola said. Invitations to receive free COVID-19 tests on campus also went out to all 667 residents of Corbett Hall and 650 fraternity and sorority members, she said.

Those students, faculty and staff members have received information on when and where to get their tests, school officials said on the school’s COVID-19 recovery website. CSU generally offers on-campus tests on Tuesdays and Fridays, according to the website.

Students, faculty and staff members can opt out of testing only for documented medical or religious reasons and may still be required to quarantine for up to 14 days, according to university policy.

CSU's volleyball, men's and women's basketball, and swimming and diving teams are all participating in voluntary workouts at Moby Arena.

The school's athletic department offices are adjacent to the arena in the McGraw Athletic Center. The weight room and training room used by athletes in all sports other than football and the academic support services for athletes are also located in Moby and the adjacent Anderson Academic Center.

The Durrell Center is a dining facility for students located just north of Moby Arena, near Westfall, Alpine, Corbett and Parmelee residence halls.

CSU is monitoring wastewater at various locations throughout campus to gauge early warning signs of infection. Wastewater data can’t be traced back to a specific person, but CSU and other entities in the state are using it to pinpoint areas where COVID-19 infection might be on the rise.

The University of Colorado found signs of COVID-19 in wastewater last week from four of its residence halls — Darley North, Darley South, Libby and Willard — in Boulder, 9News reported. Residents and employees of those residence halls were encouraged to get tested immediately for COVID-19 if they had not already done so that week. CU reported 90 new positive cases last week on its COVID-19 dashboard.

Some classes at CSU are being taught remotely this fall, but 64% have at least some in-person instruction, the university reported on its Source website.

The Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment has reported two “outbreaks” of COVID-19 on the CSU campus. Twenty-four of the university’s varsity athletes and/or staff members had tested positive as of July 21, and one other had a probable case of COVID-19. Seven members of the Kappa Sigma fraternity had tested positive as of July 23, and two other members had probable cases.

The state health department defines an outbreak as two or more lab-confirmed cases of COVID-19 in a facility or nonhousehold group with onset in a 14-day period.

Braiden Hall will likely be included in the state health department’s weekly outbreak report when it is released Wednesday.

The other cases CSU has reported have not involved multiple people from a specific classroom, residence hall or office area testing positive and therefore are not considered an outbreak by the state or county health departments, said Katie O’Donnell, a spokeswoman for the Larimer County Department of Health and Environment.

Kelly Lyell is a Coloradoan reporter. Contact him at kellylyell@coloradoan.com, follow him on Twitter @KellyLyell and find him on Facebook at www.facebook.com/KellyLyell.news. Help support Coloradoan journalists by purchasing a subscription today.
